title: 105_s448
content: The Act titled "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" addresses the interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. It introduces a new section, SEC. 4011, to regulate this aspect. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" introduces SEC. 4011, which restricts out-of-state waste disposal at landfills or incinerators without local government authorization. Authorization must be granted formally, recorded in writing, and final. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-state waste disposal, local governments must require facility owners to provide specific information, which will be made available for inspection to the Governor, adjoining local governments, Indian tribes, and interested parties. The local government must require facility owners to provide detailed information about the facility, including size, waste capacity, and anticipated quantities of waste to be handled. This information will be available for inspection by the Governor, adjoining local governments, Indian tribes, and interested parties. The facility owner must provide detailed information about the facility, including size, waste capacity, and planned expansion. This information should include a map of the facility site showing its location in relation to the local road system and environmental characteristics of the site. The facility owner must provide detailed information about the site's environmental characteristics, including ground water resources and potential alterations. This should also cover environmental controls like runon management, air pollution control devices, and monitoring programs. The facility owner must provide detailed information about environmental controls such as runoff management, air pollution control devices, methane monitoring, landfill covers, and leachate collection systems. This should also include waste residuals management, site access controls, roadway improvements, and required permits. Personnel requirements estimates should also be included. The facility owner must provide detailed information about environmental controls, waste residuals management, site access controls, and personnel requirements estimates including skill and education levels required for jobs at the facility. Additionally, a list of required permits and any information mandated by State law regarding violations must be included. The facility owner must provide information on employment statistics for skill and education levels required before and after the facility's operation. State law mandates disclosure of violations of environmental laws, enforcement proceedings, and corrective actions. Additionally, information on gifts and contributions by the owner and operator must be included. Prior to formal action, an affected local government must be notified before granting authorization to receive out-of-State municipal solid waste. State law requires disclosure of violations, corrective actions, gifts, contributions, and compliance with the State solid waste management plan. Prior to formal action, an affected local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any adjoining Indian tribes of the proposed action. Public notification through a newspaper of general circulation is required at least 30 days before a hearing, with a second notice at least 15 days before the hearing. Alternatively, State law may allow for a different form of public notification. Subsection (a) shall not apply to an operator of a landfill or incinerator if they received out-of-State waste shipments within the past year. The operator must comply with all applicable laws for landfill operation, including design standards, leachate collection, and financial assurance for closure. They must have documented authorization from the local government to accept out-of-State waste. The operator must comply with all applicable laws for landfill operation, including design standards, leachate collection, and financial assurance for closure. For incinerators, compliance with Clean Air Act requirements and state regulations on facility design is necessary. The operator must comply with Clean Air Act requirements and state laws for facility design, including documentation of municipal solid waste shipments to the Governor. Governors have the authority to restrict out-of-state waste disposal at landfills upon request by affected local governments. The Governor has the authority to limit the quantity of out-of-state municipal solid waste disposed of at landfills upon request by affected local governments and solid waste planning units. The Governor can restrict the amount of out-of-state municipal solid waste disposed of at landfills, with exemptions for certain landfills receiving specific shipments. The Governor can limit out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills, with exemptions for specific shipments. Prior to requesting this limitation, affected local governments must provide public notice and opportunity for comment. Affected local governments and solid waste planning units must provide public notice and opportunity for comment before requesting limitations on out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal. The Governor must respond to these requests without discrimination based on landfill or state of origin. The Governor must respond to requests from affected local governments regarding limitations on out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal without discrimination based on landfill or state of origin. The Governor's authority is limited if it conflicts with state law or existing disposal agreements. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator exempt from certain requirements must provide copies of disposal contracts for out-of-State municipal solid waste for public inspection in the affected local community. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must provide copies of disposal contracts for out-of-State municipal solid waste for public inspection in the affected local community. States can become exempt from these requirements by notifying the Administrator. The section applies to each State unless a State opts out by notifying the Administrator and referencing the section. The Administrator will acknowledge the State's exemption upon notification. The section defines terms like "affected local government" and "affected local solid waste planning unit" in relation to landfills and incinerators. The curr_chunk defines terms related to landfills and incinerators, including "host agreement" and "municipal solid waste." The curr_chunk defines municipal solid waste as solid waste generated by the general public or from various sources, including paper, wood, yard wastes, food wastes, plastics, leather, rubber, and other materials. It excludes hazardous waste or waste containing. The curr_chunk further specifies that municipal solid waste does not include hazardous waste, industrial waste, medical waste, or recyclable materials that have been separated from waste destined for disposal. The curr_chunk defines out-of-state municipal solid waste as waste generated outside of a specific state, and owner or operator as the individual responsible for waste management. The curr_chunk provides definitions for "out-of-state municipal solid waste" and "owner or operator" in relation to waste management facilities. The curr_chunk adds definitions for "out-of-state municipal solid waste" and "owner or operator" to the Solid Waste Disposal Act. The curr_chunk introduces regulations for interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste.
